name: conium-maculatum
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Green ovoid to suborbicular compressed laterally and wavy ribbing on the surface. Each fruit contains a single seed, and the fruits are generally called "seeds."  At maturity, fruits turn gray-brown.  The fruits ("seeds") resemble those of anise.
flower-description: Small, white 5 petaled, in terminal umbrella-like clusters with one purple flower in the center of the cluster.  Flowers appear late summer.
leaf-description: Large, 3-4 pinnately dissected, the leaflets broadly ovate to deltate very delicate and resemble parsley leaves with prominate veins on the underside.  They clasp the stems at enlarged nodes.
stem-description: Smooth, purple, brown, or red spots and fine regular lines, hollow stem foul odor when crushed.
poison-symptoms:
HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!  Delivery by ingestion.  Salivation, vomiting, diarrhea, muscular weakness, paralysis, nervousness, trembling, dilation of pupils, weak pulse, convulsions, coma.
People with highly sensitive skin may experience contact dermatitis from handling this plant.
